notesStmt.note: No image of verso currently available; according to the New York Public Library, the verso is blank, except for an annotation not in Whitman's hand.

This manuscript was likely composed in December 1864. "Visits among the Army Hospitals," published in the New York Times of December 11, 1864, included the section "Writing Letters by the Bedside." Whitman's "Hospital Scenes and Persons" from Specimen Days (1882) also includes anecdotes about Whitman's letter writing that seem to draw on these notes.

body.p: I do a good deal of this, of course. Many have not written home to parents, wives, brothers, sisters, for a long, long time. They are poor writers, have no paper or envelopes, or something else. Many have an aversion to writing because they don't want to worry the folks at home—the facts are too sad to tell. Still, I generally encourage them to write, and have written all sorts of missives, (including love letters.) Here is the l case of my writing a letter, I almost as I jot down this sketch, for a sick man to his wife.
